The first shift theorem

The first and second shift theorems enable an even wider range of Laplace transforms to be easily obtained than the transforms we have already found. They also enable a significantly wider range of inverse transforms to be found. Here we introduce the first shift theorem. If \(f(t)\) is a causal function with Laplace transform \(F(s)\), i.e. \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}=F(s)\), then as we shall see, the Laplace transform of \(\text{e}^{-at}f(t)\), where \(a\) is a given constant, can easily be found in terms of \(F(s)\).

Using the definition of the Laplace transform:

\[\begin{aligned} {\cal L}\{\text{e}^{-at}f(t)\}&= \int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-st} \biggl[\text{e}^{-at}f(t)\biggr]\,dt\\ &=\int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-(s+a)t}f(t)\,dt\end{aligned}\]

But if

\(\qquad F(s)={\cal L}\{f(t)\}=\int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-st}f(t)\,dt\)

then simply replacing ‘\(s\)’ by ‘\(s+a\)’ on both sides gives:

\(\qquad F(s+a)=\int_0^{\infty}\text{e}^{-(s+a)t}f(t)\,dt\)

That is, the parameter \(s\) is shifted to the value \(s+a\).

We have then the statement of the first shift theorem:


Key Point

First Shift Theorem

If \(\qquad{\cal L}\{f(t)\} = F(s) \qquad \)then \(\qquad {\cal L}\{\text{e}^{-at}f(t)\} = F(s+a)\)


For example, we already know (from Table 1) that

\(\qquad {\cal L}\{t^3u(t)\}={6\over {s^4}}\)

and so, by the first shift theorem:

\(\qquad {\cal L}\{\text{e}^{-2t}t^3u(t)\}={6\over {(s+2)^4}}\)
